Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Manufacturing Nanomembranes for Water Applications - In Process Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project relates to the critical issue of the nation?s and the world?s water quality and quantity. Abundant, pure, low cost water is the basis of health and prosperity. The project will produce one-atomic-layer thick membranes capable of delivering high purity water for domestic use, industry and agriculture by purification, wastewater remediation and desalination at the lowest energy possible under physical law from any water source, no matter how contaminated. With water scarcity and contamination growing issues domestically and internationally, conventional technologies either cannot perform the necessary cleanup or can only do it at costs prohibitive to agriculture, industry and daily living. By delivering an ultra-low energy solution in a small package that replaces large plants, everything from large municipalities to small towns and rural agricultural areas can benefit from high volume, low cost, high purity water at affordable prices. The technology will first be deployed in California's Central Valley to create new sources of agriculture water. At large scale for environmental remediation, it can remedy problems such as the neurotoxins that shut down Toledo, Ohio?s water or eliminate the nitrates and phosphates that caused the problem.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project represents the cutting edge of nanotechnology design and manufacturing: complete precision at the atomic scale. This membrane is made by pharmaceutical-style organic chemistry to create the most precise material ever built. It incorporates an unprecedented constellation of biomimetic techniques: using Nature's methods to reach a new level of performance in the vitally important and technically challenging area of water purification and desalination. It also represents the long-sought goal of the community of membrane researchers: ultra-low energy filtration at "high specificity", i.e., the ability to separate out very small pollutants such as removing salt from seawater, arsenic or other contaminants from freshwater. The EPA describes the relationship between water and energy as the Water/Energy Nexus. The technology takes energy requirements to the lowest energy possible under the laws of physics by working with a single atomic layer membrane. Precise construction of the pores that form the membranes enables unprecedented control over filtration and selection. Precise control over surface chemistry allows unprecedented control over issues of fouling and scaling. Successful demonstration of this technically challenging high quality manufacturing will be a game changer opening a new era of single atomic layer membranes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The total project addresses both progress in next-generation manufacturing, and contributing to solving a major problem: water crises.

The World Economic Forum’s Global Risks 2015 Report stated: “Water crises are a top global risk. Global water crises – from drought in the world’s most productive farmlands to the hundreds of millions of people without access to safe drinking water – are the biggest threat facing the planet over the next decade….It is not only the fourth time water has made the annual list that ranks the greatest risks to economies, environments and people, but the first time that water has moved into the top position for impact.

…Simply turn to just a few of the top stories of 2014:

  • The California drought becomes a US national emergency
  • New analyses describe links between drought, water management and the Syrian civil war
  • Algae blooms foul water in cities from Kunming to Toledo
  • Waterborne infectious diseases kill nearly 2 million people.”

Conservation will not solve the problem. Desalination, remediating wastewater, and removing small contaminants will be needed. Presently, 21% of California’s energy and 7 quads worldwide go just to deliver water. Using energy-intensive conventional methods, water will become more expensive and the cost of growing food, manufacturing, and daily living will rise.

What is needed is high purity water from highly compromised sources at ultra-low energy and low cost. In the overall project, Covalent has created a new, biomimetic (nature mimicking) technology of a one-atomic-layer thick membrane with custom crafted pores that can clean out small contaminants at the lowest energy possible under Nature’s laws. This combination of filtration control and low energy was described by one Department of Energy reviewer as “the long awaited breakthrough in membrane technology.”

Packaged as a shoebox-sized filtration cartridge, this membrane will essentially be an entire water treatment plant in a box producing 100,00 gallons per day with gravity feed (1PSI) as the energy source for purification, and a 10oC change to part of the system for desalination. The product is expected to cut desalination energy by 66%, and reduce CAPEX and OPEX costs 50-65% over best practices.  A 99% energy reduction for purification contribute to total water costs cuts averaging 30% for easy feedstocks, rising to 75-80% savings for challenging purifications.

The challenge is to move this novel technology from being built “by hand” to high volume manufacturing. No one has ever done bottom-up manufacturing of one-atomic-layer thick membranes before. This will be cutting edge, next generation manufacturing technology. The DOE’s Advanced Manufacturing Office has awarded grants to build massively parallel automated manufacturing units. This NSF Phase 1 grant enabled creating a realtime Quality Assurance system to monitor membrane formation and manufacturing on the DOE-sponsored unit.

Manufacturing has to be high volume, high quality and cheap. High quality is needed for membranes producing drinking water. To keep the water cheap, among other factors, the cost of the membrane itself must be kept low. A quality control system is needed to achieve these combined goals of quality and low cost.

The double challenge of a realtime QA system is:

  1. miniaturization
  2. cost reduction.

No equipment exists for large-scale commercial observation of thin film manufacturing. Conventional equipment – ellipsometry and 2 photon methods (e.g., sum frequency generation) runs $150,000 – 450,000 per unit. On the full manufacturing line, hundreds of units would be needed. The capital costs alone would be deadly for a low cost product. 

The other issue with existing equipment is its size. Each unit is about the size of large microwave oven and sits on a tabletop. To test a membrane, you would have to sacrifice it to the QA equipment. You would have to take each membrane to be tested off the manufacturing line and go over to the QA equipment to examine it. Nothing about this is useful for large-scale manufacturing.

In Phase 1, we successfully created a miniaturized QA unit. The size of a half-size Kleenex tissue box, it contains a laser, millimeter scale lenses, cameras and fiber optics. Each unit is light enough to mount on top of the manufacturing assembly and monitor membrane formation in 12 manufacturing chambers at a time.  We laid the groundwork for cost reduction down to $6,000 per unit and ultimately to $1,500 per unit. Both in terms of price and performance, it should work for creating 37,500 square feet of nanomembrane per day for each assembly line in high speed manufacturing for high quality, low cost membranes for water purification and desalination. 

First contracts are now in place with key water districts and farmers for large volume water for agriculture. This manufacturing and QA system will support farmers, manufacturers, and domestic populations with high quality water at low energy expense and low cost.
